channel.title: Comments on: Disable automatic On Disk Project syncing

item.title: By: Kathy Brown
item.dc:creator: Kathy Brown
item.description: <p>This is useful also because I have run into the scenario where automatic syncing was checked, but was not actually syncing. At least if I know it is off and I manually sync it, I won't ASSUME it is being synched (sunc?) when it isn't. If that made any sense at all.</p>
item.content:encoded: This is useful also because I have run into the scenario where automatic syncing was checked, but was not actually syncing. At least if I know it is off and I manually sync it, I won’t ASSUME it is being synched (sunc?) when it isn’t. If that made any sense at all.

item.title: By: Andrew Magerman
item.dc:creator: Andrew Magerman
item.description: <p>Excellent tip matt. That dialog box had led me to disable source control, since it was driving me craaazy.</p>
item.content:encoded: Excellent tip matt. That dialog box had led me to disable source control, since it was driving me craaazy.

item.title: By: Paul Withers
item.dc:creator: Paul Withers
item.content:encoded:
That’s a great tip, but one gotcha to be aware of (I fell into it myself). If you open a database in Designer, deselecting these options means it doesn’t automatically open the referenced on-disk project. This really threw me, because I was sure I had set up source control, but the Team Development context menu only gave options to set up source control or associate with an on-disk project. But I was sure I already had an on-disk project, but couldn’t remember the name.

Once I opened the relevant on-disk project, the Team Development (right-click) context menu gave the options I expected.

Again, not a huge pain because I can temporarily re-enable the settings if I really need to. But it threw me for a little while.
